questions.text: A 55-year-old man with a history of chronic heart failure is admitted to the hospital following an episode of acute chest pain. On examination, his heart rate is elevated, and an ECG shows signs consistent with myocardial ischemia. Laboratory findings indicate elevated cardiac enzymes. The patient's condition leads to a discussion among the medical team about the cellular mechanisms of injury in myocardial ischemia. One of the team members mentions that a diminished supply of ATP is a critical factor in the pathophysiology of this condition. Which of the following is a direct consequence of diminished ATP in the context of cellular injury during myocardial ischemia?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Mitochondrial dysfunction

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The educational objective is to recognize the role of mitochondrial dysfunction as a primary and direct consequence of diminished ATP production in the setting of cellular injury, such as in myocardial ischemia. Mitochondria are crucial for ATP synthesis, and their dysfunction underlies many pathophysiological processes associated with ischemic conditions. Understanding the link between impaired oxygen supply, mitochondrial dysfunction, and reduced ATP production is fundamental for medical professionals managing patients with conditions like myocardial ischemia.
  • ➤ The educational objective is to recognize the role of mitochondrial dysfunction as a primary and direct consequence of diminished ATP production in the setting of cellular injury, such as in myocardial ischemia.
  • ➤ Mitochondria are crucial for ATP synthesis, and their dysfunction underlies many pathophysiological processes associated with ischemic conditions.
  • ➤ Understanding the link between impaired oxygen supply, mitochondrial dysfunction, and reduced ATP production is fundamental for medical professionals managing patients with conditions like myocardial ischemia.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man with a 5-year history of Parkinson's disease is seen in the clinic for a follow-up visit. He has been on levodopa/carbidopa therapy but reports increasing periods of immobility. His neurologist is considering adding another medication to help reduce these off periods. questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The key educational objective is to understand the pharmacological management of Parkinson's disease, particularly the role of tolcapone. Tolcapone is a catechol-O-methyltransferase (COMT) inhibitor used to increase the bioavailability of levodopa in the brain, thereby reducing "off" periods in patients with Parkinson's disease. It is important to differentiate between the mechanisms of action of various drugs used in Parkinson's disease treatment, such as COMT inhibitors (like tolcapone), MAO-B inhibitors (like selegiline), dopamine agonists (like rotigotine), and others (like amantadine).
  • ➤ The key educational objective is to understand the pharmacological management of Parkinson's disease, particularly the role of tolcapone.

questions.text: In a District hospital, a casualty medical officer was faced with a peculiar case. A group of hikers had discovered a body in a densely wooded area on the outskirts of the city. questions.text: A 24-year-old woman delivers a 3.4 kg baby at 38 weeks’ gestation using outlet forceps due to a prolonged second stage of labor. Following the successful delivery of the baby and the complete delivery of the placenta, she experiences profuse bleeding. The uterus is found to be well-contracted upon examination. Further examination of the vagina and cervix reveals a cervical tear. Given this scenario, what would be the most appropriate next step in management?

options.label: A
options.text: Pack the cervix and remove the pack after 4-6 hours

options.label: C
options.text: Laparotomy and suture the cervical tear from above

questions.correct_answer: B. Suture the cervical tear vaginally
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ This question highlights the importance of promptly identifying and managing cervical tears following delivery, especially when they are the source of significant postpartum hemorrhage. Direct suturing of the tear via a vaginal approach is often the most appropriate and effective intervention. Other management strategies, such as cervical packing or the use of anti-fibrinolytics, may have a role in specific contexts but are not the primary treatment for a cervical tear. Laparotomy is generally reserved for more complex cases where vaginal access is not sufficient or other intra-abdominal injuries are suspected.
  • ➤ This question highlights the importance of promptly identifying and managing cervical tears following delivery, especially when they are the source of significant postpartum hemorrhage.
  • ➤ Direct suturing of the tear via a vaginal approach is often the most appropriate and effective intervention.
  • ➤ Other management strategies, such as cervical packing or the use of anti-fibrinolytics, may have a role in specific contexts but are not the primary treatment for a cervical tear.
  • ➤ Laparotomy is generally reserved for more complex cases where vaginal access is not sufficient or other intra-abdominal injuries are suspected.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child presents to the clinic with a sore throat, fever, and difficulty swallowing for the past two days. The child's mother reports that the child has had similar episodes in the past. Considering the anatomical origin of the affected structure, where do the tonsils develop from?
questions.correct_answer: B. Develops from Second Pharyngeal Pouch
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Develops from Second Pharyngeal Pouch

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 26-year-old professional soccer player presents to the clinic with acute ankle pain following a severe inversion injury during a match. Physical examination reveals significant tenderness and swelling over the medial aspect of the ankle. Radiographic imaging is negative for fractures but suggests a ligamentous injury. The physician suspects injury to a specific component of the medial (deltoid) ligament complex, which is crucial for resisting valgus stress and providing stability to the medial side of the ankle. Which part of the deltoid ligament is most likely involved in this patient's injury?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Tibio-calcaneal part

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ This question aims to assess the learner's understanding of the anatomy and function of the deltoid ligament, particularly the tibio-calcaneal part, in providing medial ankle stability. Recognizing the specific components of the deltoid ligament and their roles in ankle stability is crucial for diagnosing ligamentous injuries and guiding appropriate treatment, especially in athletes who sustain inversion injuries of the ankle. Understanding the mechanism of injury and the anatomical structures involved is essential for accurate diagnosis, management, and prevention of further injury in clinical practice.
  • ➤ This question aims to assess the learner's understanding of the anatomy and function of the deltoid ligament, particularly the tibio-calcaneal part, in providing medial ankle stability.

  • ➤ Understanding the mechanism of injury and the anatomical structures involved is essential for accurate diagnosis, management, and prevention of further injury in clinical practice.

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient with a history of diabetes mellitus presents to the emergency department with acute onset of high fever, chills, and painful urination. The patient also complains of flank pain and nausea. Urinalysis reveals significant leukocyturia and glycosuria. Given the patient's diabetic status and the acute presentation, a CT scan of the abdomen is performed to further evaluate the cause of these symptoms. Based on the clinical presentation and the patient's background, which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The question is designed to test the ability to recognize and differentiate between severe urinary tract infections in diabetic patients, particularly focusing on emphysematous pyelonephritis. It underscores the importance of considering this life-threatening condition when a diabetic patient presents with symptoms of a UTI and emphasizes the role of imaging, such as a CT scan, in diagnosing emphysematous pyelonephritis by identifying gas within the renal tissues. Understanding the distinctions between acute pyelonephritis, perinephric abscess, and renal abscess is essential for accurate diagnosis and effective management.
  • ➤ The question is designed to test the ability to recognize and differentiate between severe urinary tract infections in diabetic patients, particularly focusing on emphysematous pyelonephritis.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman, gravida 2 para 1, who previously underwent an uncomplicated lower segment cesarean section, is currently in labor and has been deemed a candidate for a trial of labor after cesarean (TOLAC). The medical team is closely monitoring for any signs of complications, particularly uterine scar rupture, due to her history of cesarean delivery. In this scenario, which of the following is considered the earliest warning sign of uterine scar rupture?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Fetal distress

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The earliest warning sign of uterine scar rupture during a trial of labor after cesarean (TOLAC) is often fetal distress, detected as abnormal fetal heart rate patterns. Continuous fetal monitoring is essential in TOLAC to detect such changes promptly, allowing for immediate evaluation and intervention to ensure the safety of both mother and fetus. Other signs like severe abdominal pain, vaginal bleeding, and maternal tachycardia, while important, may manifest later or be less specific to uterine rupture.
  • ➤ The earliest warning sign of uterine scar rupture during a trial of labor after cesarean (TOLAC) is often fetal distress, detected as abnormal fetal heart rate patterns.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman has noted enlargement of her anterior neck region over the past 8 months. On physical examination, her vital signs include Temperature of 36.8°C, Pulse rate of 64/minute, RR of 16/minute, and BP of 155/105 mm Hg. There is diffuse, symmetrical thyroid enlargement without tenderness. A chest radiograph is normal. Fine needle aspiration of the thyroid yields cells consistent with a neoplasm. Laboratory studies show that she is euthyroid, but her serum ionized calcium is elevated. She is taken to surgery and frozen sections of several thyroid masses show a malignant neoplasm composed of polygonal cells in nests. A thyroidectomy is performed. Immunostaining for calcitonin of the permanent sections is positive, and the neoplasm has an amyloid stroma with Congo red staining. Which of the following neoplasms is she most likely to have?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Medullary carcinoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The diagnosis of medullary thyroid carcinoma is supported by the clinical presentation of a thyroid mass, the histological findings of polygonal cells arranged in nests with amyloid stroma, positive calcitonin immunostaining, and associated hypercalcemia. Medullary thyroid carcinoma is a distinct entity from other forms of thyroid cancer, with unique clinical, histological, and biochemical profiles.
  • ➤ The diagnosis of medullary thyroid carcinoma is supported by the clinical presentation of a thyroid mass, the histological findings of polygonal cells arranged in nests with amyloid stroma, positive calcitonin immunostaining, and associated hypercalcemia.
  • ➤ Medullary thyroid carcinoma is a distinct entity from other forms of thyroid cancer, with unique clinical, histological, and biochemical profiles.

questions.text: A 26-year-old man has the onset of nausea and lethargy over the past 3 days. On physical examination, his blood pressure is 146/94 mm Hg. His serum creatinine is 4.4 mg/dL. Urinalysis shows hematuria and proteinuria. He has anti-glomerular basement membrane antibody. A renal biopsy is performed and the microscopic appearance with H&E stain is shown here. Which of the following historical findings is this patient most likely to provide?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Recent hemoptysis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The image provided is indicative of anti-glomerular basement membrane disease, also known as Goodpasture syndrome , which often presents with both renal and pulmonary symptoms, including hemoptysis. It is characterized by the presence of anti-glomerular basement membrane antibodies and the associated clinical findings of renal failure (elevated creatinine, hematuria, and proteinuria). The diagnosis can be confirmed with a renal biopsy showing characteristic histological findings.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman presents to the outpatient department accompanied by her anxious mother-in-law, concerned about the inability to conceive since her marriage 8 months ago. The patient reports having regular menstrual cycles and a coital frequency of approximately three times per week. Given this information, what is the next best step in managing this patient's concerns?
questions.correct_answer: D. Explanation of the fertile period
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Explanation of the fertile period

Explanation:

  • • Ans. D) Explanation of the fertile period
  • • The most appropriate next step is to provide education on the fertile period. The couple has only been attempting conception for 8 months, and infertility is typically defined as the inability to conceive after 12 months of regular, unprotected intercourse. Given the regular menstrual cycles and adequate coital frequency, it's crucial to ensure that the couple is well-informed about the timing of the fertile window, which is the period during a woman's cycle when conception is most likely to occur. This usually spans 5 days before and includes the day of ovulation, typically around the 14th day of a 28-day menstrual cycle.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female presents to the clinic with complaints of intermittent jaundice that seems to worsen during periods of illness or stress. She reports no pain, pruritus, or changes in stool or urine colour. Her family history is notable for similar symptoms in her mother. Laboratory tests reveal a mild elevation in total and direct bilirubin, with normal liver enzymes and no evidence of hemolysis. An abdominal ultrasound shows no abnormalities in the liver or bile ducts. Histological examination shows deposition of brown-black melanin-like pigment in the hepatocyte. Based on her clinical presentation, which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Dubin-Johnson Syndrome

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Option A. Gilbert's Syndrome . This is a common, benign condition characterized by mild unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia, especially during fasting or stress. Unlike Dubin-Johnson Syndrome, it involves an increase in indirect bilirubin and normal liver histology.
  • • Option A. Gilbert's Syndrome
  • • Option B. Crigler-Najjar Syndrome Type I . A severe form of unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia due to the absence of the enzyme uridine diphosphate glucuronosyltransferase. It is associated with high levels of indirect bilirubin and can lead to kernicterus if untreated. The presentation is more severe than Dubin-Johnson Syndrome.
  • • Option B. Crigler-Najjar Syndrome Type I
  • • Option D. Rotor Syndrome . Similar to Dubin-Johnson Syndrome in clinical presentation but without the liver pigment deposition. It is also an autosomal recessive condition characterized by chronic or intermittent conjugated hyperbilirubinemia but without the characteristic liver histology seen in Dubin-Johnson Syndrome.
  • • Option D. Rotor Syndrome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The question aims to test the ability to differentiate between various hereditary disorders presenting with jaundice, focusing on Dubin-Johnson Syndrome.
  • ➤ It emphasizes understanding the clinical presentation, inheritance patterns, laboratory findings, and histological features distinguishing Dubin-Johnson Syndrome from other conditions like Gilbert's Syndrome, Crigler-Najjar Syndrome, and Rotor Syndrome.
  • ➤ Recognizing these differences is crucial for accurate diagnosis and management of patients presenting with jaundice and hyperbilirubinemia.

The patient also notes that he occasionally regurgitates undigested food shortly after eating, which is particularly distressing during social meals. He denies any significant weight loss, changes in appetite, or gastrointestinal bleeding. His past medical history is unremarkable, and he is not on any regular medications. Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective

This condition is characterized by the formation of a diverticulum at the pharyngoesophageal junction, which can trap food and lead to regurgitation. Other conditions, such as Mallory-Weiss tears, Schatzki rings, and traction diverticula, affect the esophagus differently and present with distinct clinical features that help differentiate them from Zenker’s diverticulum.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man has had a progressively worsening productive cough for one month. On physical examination, a few small non-tender lymph nodes are palpable in the axillae, and the tip of the spleen is palpable. Laboratory studies show Hgb 10.2 g/dL, Hct 31.1%, MCV 90 fL, WBC count 67,000/microliter, and platelet count 36,000/microliter. Microscopic examination of his peripheral blood smear shows many blasts with Auer rods. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Acute myelogenous leukemia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The diagnosis of acute myelogenous leukemia is supported by clinical findings such as anemia, thrombocytopenia, splenomegaly, and a high white blood cell count with the presence of myeloblasts containing Auer rods on a peripheral blood smear. Auer rods are pathognomonic for a myeloid lineage malignancy, specifically AML.
  • ➤ The diagnosis of acute myelogenous leukemia is supported by clinical findings such as anemia, thrombocytopenia, splenomegaly, and a high white blood cell count with the presence of myeloblasts containing Auer rods on a peripheral blood smear.
  • ➤ Auer rods are pathognomonic for a myeloid lineage malignancy, specifically AML.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents to the clinic with complaints of muscle weakness and decreased sensitivity in his left arm. On examination, you note that his reflexes are diminished in the affected arm. You recall that muscle spindles play a critical role in proprioception and reflex regulation. Muscle spindles contain intrafusal fibres that are essential for sensing changes in muscle length and initiating reflexive responses to maintain muscle tone and posture. Given the importance of muscle spindles in proprioception and reflex regulation, which of the following nerve fibres is primarily responsible for the motor supply to the intrafusal muscle fibres within these spindles?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The primary objective of this question is to understand the role of gamma motor neurons in proprioception and reflex regulation. Gamma motor neurons innervate the intrafusal muscle fibres within muscle spindles, adjusting their sensitivity to changes in muscle length and thereby modulating the stretch reflex. This is crucial for maintaining muscle tone and posture. Alpha motor neurons control the contraction of extrafusal muscle fibres, while beta motor neurons have a less specific role, innervating both intrafusal and extrafusal fibres. Delta fibres are sensory and not involved in motor control of muscle spindles.
  • ➤ The primary objective of this question is to understand the role of gamma motor neurons in proprioception and reflex regulation.
  • ➤ Gamma motor neurons innervate the intrafusal muscle fibres within muscle spindles, adjusting their sensitivity to changes in muscle length and thereby modulating the stretch reflex.
  • ➤ This is crucial for maintaining muscle tone and posture.
  • ➤ Alpha motor neurons control the contraction of extrafusal muscle fibres, while beta motor neurons have a less specific role, innervating both intrafusal and extrafusal fibres.
  • ➤ Delta fibres are sensory and not involved in motor control of muscle spindles.

questions.text: A 55-year-old previously healthy man has developed progressive renal failure for the past 5 years along with back pain. Understanding the associations between hematologic malignancies and renal pathology is critical for the diagnosis and management of these conditions.
  • ➤ The objective of this question is to recognize the clinical and pathological features of amyloidosis associated with multiple myeloma.

questions.text: A 24-year-old primigravida is seen for a routine prenatal visit at 36 weeks of gestation. On examination, the uterus appears smaller than expected for gestational age, with the symphysio-fundal height measuring 31 cm, suggesting the uterus corresponds to approximately 32 weeks of gestation rather than 36. Educational Objective:

An ultrasound for biometry is the most appropriate next step to assess fetal size, growth pattern, and amniotic fluid volume, which are crucial for managing potential complications such as intrauterine growth restriction. Other options like biophysical profile, daily fetal movement count, and non-stress test are valuable for ongoing fetal surveillance but are not the primary tools for initially assessing fetal growth discrepancies.

questions.text: The process of insulin release in response to elevated blood glucose levels represents a finely tuned physiological mechanism critical for maintaining metabolic equilibrium. The phenomena of Glucose-mediated insulin release involves:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) ATP-Sensitive K+ Channels

Educational Objective:

The ATP inhibits ATP-sensitive K+ channels , reducing K+ efflux → depolarization and opening of voltage-gated Ca 2+ channels . The Ca 2+ influx causes exocytosis of a readily releasable pool of insulin-containing secretory granules , producing the initial spike of insulin secretion .

questions.text: A 25-year-old male patient with a history of seizures presents to the clinic. He has been taking anticonvulsants for the last few years, and he reports experiencing visual disturbances, including a narrowing of his visual field. He is concerned about the possibility of permanent vision loss. Which of these anticonvulsants causes contraction of visual field?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C

Educational Objective:

It underscores the need for regular ophthalmologic evaluations in patients taking vigabatrin to monitor for this serious adverse effect and illustrates the diverse side effect profiles of anticonvulsant drugs.

questions.text: In modern obstetrics, which of the following investigations is used for monitoring the fetus of an Rh-negative sensitized mother?

options.label: D
options.text: MCA (Middle cerebral artery) doppler peak systolic velocity

questions.correct_answer: D. MCA (Middle cerebral artery) doppler peak systolic velocity
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) MCA (Middle cerebral artery) doppler peak systolic velocity

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objectives:
  • ➤ A Doppler of the middle cerebral artery indirectly gives evidence of fetal anemia. An anemic fetus (For e.g. due to fetal red cell destruction in an Rh iso-immunized mother) will re-direct blood flow to more important organs like the brain. This is reflected by an increased flow in the middle cerebral artery which can be measured by doing a Doppler of the MCA. In Rh immunized mothers, when indirect Coomb’s Test (ICT) titers rise above the critical titer of 1:16, then MCA doppler peak systolic velocity (PSV) is used for monitoring fetal anemia and development of hydrops in these babies. MCA-PSV has replaced amniocentesis as it is a non-invasive test.
  • ➤ A Doppler of the middle cerebral artery indirectly gives evidence of fetal anemia.
  • ➤ An anemic fetus (For e.g. due to fetal red cell destruction in an Rh iso-immunized mother) will re-direct blood flow to more important organs like the brain.
  • ➤ This is reflected by an increased flow in the middle cerebral artery which can be measured by doing a Doppler of the MCA.
  • ➤ In Rh immunized mothers, when indirect Coomb’s Test (ICT) titers rise above the critical titer of 1:16, then MCA doppler peak systolic velocity (PSV) is used for monitoring fetal anemia and development of hydrops in these babies.
  • ➤ MCA-PSV has replaced amniocentesis as it is a non-invasive test.

questions.text: A 54-year-old man is being treated for a pulmonary abscess. He has received broad spectrum antibiotic therapy with nafcillin, cephalosporins, and gentamicin for the past 14 days. He has developed abdominal pain, fever, and diarrhea over the past 3 days. The gross appearance of his colonic mucosa is shown here. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Pseudomembranous colitis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ This question tests the ability to recognize pseudomembranous colitis's clinical presentation and characteristic endoscopic findings. It's crucial to identify this condition given its association with recent antibiotic use and the potential for severe complications. Understanding the differences in presentation and endoscopic findings among various colitides is important for accurate diagnosis and appropriate treatment.
